awd_titl_txt: SCC-PG: JST: Multimodal Data Analytics and Integration for Emergency Response and Disaster Management
awd_abstract_narration:
The prevalence of high-speed data management and communication systems have produced countless large volumes of high-veracity, real-time data collections across many domains. For example, natural disasters initiate a myriad of human communications, data exchange, and situational assessments. It is crucial to quickly collect and analyze all of the relevant data, as life or death decisions may rest on the outcome. Hurricane Irma in 2017 caused the largest civil evacuation in Florida’s history and emphasizes two critical problems in emergency management: 1) pre-storm evacuation coordination; and 2) post-storm support for shelter-in-place locations. Disaster information integration and fusion technologies have the potential to deliver enhanced situational awareness tools across all sectors, enabling a more efficient, effective, and automated emergency management and recovery process. However, there is no discernible approach to identify and exploit the underlying patterns of each dataset while also minimizing possible drawbacks. This project aims to utilize multimodal data, such as text messages, images, videos, traffic information, and geo-referencing information, from various sources including social media, news, government announcements, and radio broadcasts. This work will investigate the analysis and fusion of this information to provide useful insights for aiding the decision-making process for both residents and government agencies. The goal is to develop new tools and technologies that can support emergency managers to better evaluate the effectiveness of disaster management policies such as evacuation. 

The proposed research provides potential solutions to solve crucial information analysis challenges related to disaster information management while leveraging the team's previous work. In addition, the team's research approach offers rapid key information identification, efficient multimodal data integration that facilitates emergency management, and enhances dynamic community disaster information sharing. Moreover, solutions developed could later be extended to other domains in the information management field. This project fosters collaboration among two institutions, Florida International University (FIU) and University of Tokyo, as well as institutions across the public and private sectors, to develop advanced techniques for effective emergency response and disaster management. The broader impact of this work will lead to scientific advances in the preparation, response, recovery, and mitigation of major disasters. As the largest graduate Hispanic Serving Institution in the continental United States, FIU will also benefit from the impact of this project that expands the participation of underrepresented groups in STEM fields. The research findings of this project will be broadly disseminated via publications, presentations, and an organized workshop.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award fostered the international collaboration between US and Japan teams from the Florida International University and The University of Tokyo and prepared the teams to get ready for developing data-driven tools to aid emergency managers for emergency response and disaster management. Disasters initiate a myriad of human communications, data exchange, and situational assessments. It is crucial to quickly collect and analyze all the relevant data as life or death decisions may rest on the outcome, which can facilitate emergence responses and disaster management. Therefore, in this project, the research team has conducted research to answer the following three questions: (1) How we can collect the data essential for disaster management and response; (2) What forms of data integration, fusion, and visualization will aid emergency responders, and how these tools can be used to improve disaster response; and (3) How population mobility data can be utilized to help formulate disaster evacuation planning.

The research team gathered a collection of multimodal data, including social media, mobility, and other disaster-related information, to effectively improve situation monitoring, estimation, and prediction for disaster management. A number of community-identified applications were developed to facilitate disaster management and support decision making for the managers. Specifically, we found it important to identify the communities in crisis after disaster events. The research framework for the in-crisis community identification problem has been designed by integrating expertises from both US and Japan teams. Meanwhile, data-driven analytics techniques to process disaster-related multimedia data for disaster scene detection, building damage estimation, human mobility nowcasting during disasters, etc., have been investigated and developed.

In response to the emerging challenges due to COVID-19 pandemic, we have also investigated potentials of pandemic management based on the proposed framework of this project. To better understand the art of the existing data-driven approaches in COVID-19 and pandemic management, the team conducted a comprehensive survey on data-driven methods for COVID-19 management and existing public data sources for COVID-19. On top of that, the infection prediction model under various mobility restriction policies, as well as techniques to estimate economic impacts of pandemics, have been tackled. Currently, in total, 11 journal and conference articles have been published or accepted for publication in the top venues in the related domains, such as artificial intelligence, data mining, and disaster management.

During the research and development, the team closely worked with the community stakeholders and partners to understand the problems in practice and validate the usefulness of the proposed research ideas. The research team has delivered the integrated analysis based on the developed research outcomes to support public authorities, including the Miami-Dade Emergency Operations Center, Cabinet Office of Japan, Tokyo Metropolis Government, and Nagasaki Prefecture Government.

Furthermore, two workshops were held to gather community stakeholders, county representatives, and institute and academy members and to obtain feedback and suggestions from the community. In the first workshop, titled ?Hurricanes and COVID-19: Impact and Lessons Learned,? we engaged with multiple upper ranks of emergency managers from Miami-Dade Emergency Operations Center and learned the pain points that can arise when dealing with hurricanes along with COVID-19. In the second workshop, titled ?Hurricanes and COVID-19: Lessons Learned and Directions for the Future,? we brought together multidisciplinary researchers with expertise in disaster management to provide an open dialog to exchange ideas and generate new research topics regarding responding to the hurricanes while considering the impact of COVID-19. Some valuable research directions, such as utilizing multimodal information on the internet of things (IoT) and smart cities to enable the formation of efficient disaster management systems, were discussed. We refined and solidified our research plan based on the discussions and obtained feedback from both workshops.

The broader impacts of this project have been three-fold. First, the proposed techniques have provided the opportunities to build a first-of-its-kind framework to better understand the disaster situation to assist the disaster preparation and recovery for the community while our preliminary studies have illustrated the effectiveness of multimodal data integration in solving many use-inspired problems in disaster management; Second, the developed multimodal data analyses could enable effective and continuous monitoring and understanding of the people under the impact of disasters and the communities in crisis. The proposed techniques in this project can prevent unexpected losses by avoiding inappropriate policies and supporting decision-making during disasters in United States, Japan, and all other counties and regions over the world; Third, this project provides a new computational approach to analyze and synthesize the data of human behaviors, geographical information, economic and societal status, etc. Such methods can be broadly applied to many other fields and domains, such as geographical information system, social science research, epidemiology modeling, and public health applications.
